title: Observing With NASA
subtitle: Learn how to enhance real NASA data. Choose a challenge below.

splash2.title: How are NASA’s amazing images of space created?
splash2.header: Create your own astrophotos in two different ways:
splash2.intro1: Use real images captured by NASA telescopes and make scientific or artistic choices to apply colors and manipulate the data.
splash2.intro2: Capture your own real earth-based telescope image using a MicroObservatory Robotic Telescope tonight.

communicationError: TECHNICAL DIFFICULTY: There may be a delay in processing your request.

telescopeData.prologue: These images were taken with the

telescopes.name: Hubble
description: The Hubble Space Telescope (HST) is perhaps the most famous of NASA’s orbiting telescopes.
Over more than 30 years, it has made more than a million observations, capturing amazing
and awe-inspiring images of planets, stars, nebulas, and galaxies.
Hubble was built to be a versatile telescope able to detect light in ultra-violet,
The telescope is named after famous astronomer Edwin Hubble, who first discovered
evidence that the universe is expanding.

telescopes.name: Chandra
description: NASA’s Chandra X-ray Observatory is a flagship mission specially designed to detect X-rays from
the high-energy universe. This space telescope is named in honor of Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar,
a famous Indian-American astrophysicist and Nobel laureate.
Elliptical orbit around Earth that reaches ⅓ the way to the Moon
Chandra’s goal is to detect X-ray emission from very hot regions of the Universe such as
exploded stars, clusters of galaxies, and matter around black holes.
The Space Shuttle mission that deployed Chandra into orbit was the first commanded by a

telescopes.name: Spitzer
description: The Spitzer Space Telescope was designed to detect longer-wavelength infrared light that is invisible to
human eyes and optical telescopes. Infrared radiation is emitted from cosmic regions that are not quite hot
enough to glow with visible light, such as clouds of dust and molecules among the stars.
Spitzer was built specifically to detect infrared wavelengths of light, which are emitted by distant
galaxies, dust surrounding forming stars, near-Earth asteroids, and by exoplanets orbiting in other
Along with the Hubble Space Telescope, the Chandra X-ray Observatory, and the Compton Gamma Ray Observatory,
Spitzer was one of NASA’s four “Great Observatories” built to capture light across the spectrum.

telescopes.name: LRO
description: LRO is a NASA robotic spacecraft currently orbiting the Moon in an orbit that takes it around the Moon’s poles.
The highest resolution images of the LRO Camera can resolve features down to a few meters across.
LRO was built to create detailed maps of the lunar surface to identify safe landing sites and to help plan
for NASA’s future human and robotic missions to the Moon.
LRO has detected evidence that there is frozen water at the poles of the Moon.

telescopes.name: Juno
description: Juno is a NASA spacecraft orbiting the planet Jupiter. It carries multiple instruments to measure
Jupiter’s gravity and magnetic fields. Juno investigates Jupiter’s atmosphere with ultraviolet, infrared,
In a series of elliptical orbits around Jupiter
Juno’s primary goal is to gather data from beneath Jupiter’s dense clouds to help us understand how Jupiter
JunoCam — the camera that regularly takes red, green, and blue-filtered images of Jupiter’s colorful
atmosphere — was specifically designed for public astrophotographers like YOU!

telescopes.name: SDO
description: The Solar Dynamic Observatory (SDO) has been observing the Sun for more than a decade, helping to see our
closest star “in a new light.” Ultraviolet images from SDO show the hot and active regions of the Sun’s
upper atmosphere, or corona, that are invisible to human eyes.
In geosynchronous Earth orbit, 22,000 miles above its ground station in New Mexico.
SDO was designed to help us understand how the Sun’s magnetic field and solar activity influences
life on Earth and human technological systems.
SDO’s instruments capture images from the Sun in 10 different wavelengths every 10 seconds. Over
more than ten years SDO has provided scientists with hundreds of millions of images of our star!

categories.title: Find the Apollo Site
categories.subtitle: Investigate small details in these high resolution images to locate where humans landed on the moon.

pages.title: Apollo 11
pages.subtitle:
Investigate small details in these high resolution images to locate
where humans landed on the moon.
pages.findtext: Find the Apollo 11 site pictured below
pages.saveandsendtext: This high-resolution map of the Moon’s surface was made by NASA’s Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter.
pages.saveandsendtext1: This high-resolution map of the Moon’s surface was made by NASA’s
pages.context: In July, 1969, Apollo 11 carried the first humans to the surface of the Moon. NASA chose a landing site that was flat, smooth, and with relatively few craters.

pages.title: Apollo 12
pages.subtitle: Investigate small details in these high resolution images to locate where humans landed on the moon.
pages.findtext: Find the Apollo 12 site pictured below
pages.saveandsendtext: This high-resolution map of the Moon’s surface was made by NASA’s Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter.
pages.saveandsendtext1: This high-resolution map of the Moon’s surface was made by NASA’s
pages.context: The Apollo 12 Lunar Module landed on the Moon’s surface in November of 1969. This mission achieved a precision landing, just 535 feet from an earlier robotic spacecraft named Surveyor 3.

pages.title: Apollo 14
pages.subtitle:
Investigate small details in these high resolution images to locate
where humans landed on the moon.
pages.findtext: Find the Apollo 14 site pictured below
pages.saveandsendtext: This high-resolution map of the Moon’s surface was made by NASA’s Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter.
pages.saveandsendtext1: This high-resolution map of the Moon’s surface was made by NASA’s
pages.context: Apollo 14 (January 31, 1971 - February 9, 1971) was the third crewed mission to land on the Moon, after an on-board explosion forced Apollo 13 to return to Earth in a dramatic rescue operation.

pages.title: Apollo 15
pages.subtitle:
Investigate small details in these high resolution images to locate
where humans landed on the moon.
pages.findtext: Find the Apollo 15 site pictured below
pages.saveandsendtext: This high-resolution map of the Moon’s surface was made by NASA’s Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter.
pages.saveandsendtext1: This high-resolution map of the Moon’s surface was made by NASA’s
pages.context: Apollo 15 took place from July 26, 1971 to August 7, 1971, and landed near a rugged mountain range named after the Italian Apennines. This mission was the first where astronauts used a Lunar Roving Vehicle.

pages.title: Apollo 16

pages.saveandsendtext1: This high-resolution map of the Moon’s surface was made by NASA’s
pages.context: Apollo 16 landed in the lunar highlands, where the astronauts collected rocks to look for evidence of volcanic activity. No such evidence was found.

categories.title: Animate Images Over Time
categories.subtitle: Look for patterns of change in a series of images the same way scientists do.

pages.title: Jupiter
pages.subtitle: Look for patterns of change in a series of images the same way scientists do.
pages.animatetext: Use the arrows to move through these images or play them on a loop. See what you can learn.
pages.context: These images show two changing features of Jupiter over a period of hours: the motion of storms in its atmosphere and the paths and shadows of orbiting moons.
pages.saveandsendtext: This image is one in a series taken by the Hubble Space Telescope - and explored by YOU!
pages.saveandsendtext1: This image was taken by the

pages.title: Sun-Ultraviolet
pages.subtitle: Scientists use sequences of images like these to investigate how objects in space form, move, and change over time
pages.animatetext: Use the arrows to move through these images or play them on a loop. See what you can learn.
pages.context: These images show solar storms changing as the Sun rotates over several days. These magnetic storms show up best in ultraviolet images like this.
pages.saveandsendtext: This image is one in a series taken by the Solar Dynamics Observatory - and explored by YOU!
pages.saveandsendtext1: This image was taken by the

categories.title: Reveal an Image using “Invisible Light”
categories.subtitle: Reveal the secrets of objects in space. NASA uses space telescopes that see wavelengths of light invisible to human eyes.

pages.title: Cigar Galaxy
pages.subtitle: Combine these images and reveal the secrets of objects in space. NASA uses space telescopes that see wavelengths of light invisible to human eyes.
pages.context: Multiwavelength images reveal the explosion of gas from the center of this galaxy.
pages.selectfiltertext: Find out more about what each wavelength of light can tell us about objects in space.
pages.adjustimagetext: Use these sliders to show more detail in the image
pages.saveandsendtext: This image was taken by one or more of the Spitzer, Hubble, and Chandra Space Telescopes - and enhanced by YOU!

sources.name: Infrared
sources.context: The Spitzer Space Telescope captures the infrared light emitted by the plumes of dust being blown away from the center of this starburst galaxy.

sources.name: Optical
sources.context: Hubble’s optical camera sees the cigar-shaped disk of this galaxy and the dark dust being blown from its center.

sources.name: X-Ray
sources.context: The Chandra X-ray Observatory detects huge bubbles of hot gas expanding from supernova explosions in this galaxy’s core. The image also reveals lots of point sources, many of which are black holes!

pages.title: Whirlpool Galaxy
pages.subtitle: Combine these images and reveal the secrets of objects in space. NASA uses space telescopes that see wavelengths of light invisible to human eyes.
pages.context: Infrared reveals the glowing dust in the spiral arms. X-Rays reveal the location of black holes.
pages.selectfiltertext: Find out more about what each wavelength of light can tell us about objects in space.
pages.adjustimagetext: Use these sliders to show more detail in the image
pages.saveandsendtext: This image was taken by one or more of the Spitzer, Hubble, and Chandra Space Telescopes - and enhanced by YOU!

sources.name: Infrared
sources.context: The Spitzer Space Telescope captures the infrared light emitted by all the dust in the spiral arms of the galaxy. These dust lanes appear dark in optical light.

sources.name: Optical
sources.context: Hubble’s optical camera captures the light of the billions of stars in this spiral shaped galaxy. Dark spiral lanes of dust block the visible starlight, but shine brightly in infrared light.

sources.name: X-Ray
sources.context: The Chandra X-ray Observatory reveals the location of hundreds of point sources in the galaxy -- including neutron stars and black holes.

pages.title: Lagoon Galaxy
pages.subtitle: Combine these images and reveal the secrets of objects in space. NASA uses space telescopes that see wavelengths of light invisible to human eyes.
pages.context: Multiwavelength images reveal the explosion of gas from the center of this galaxy.
pages.selectfiltertext: Find out more about what each wavelength of light can tell us about objects in space.
pages.adjustimagetext: Use these sliders to show more detail in the image
pages.saveandsendtext: This image was taken by one or more of the Spitzer, Hubble, and Chandra Space Telescopes - and enhanced by YOU!

sources.name: Infrared
sources.context: The Spitzer Space Telescope captures the infrared light emitted by all the young stars inside the dusty cocoon of the Lagoon Nebula. These stars are hidden if viewed with an optical telescope.

sources.name: Optical
sources.context: Hubble’s optical camera captures the amazing shape of the clouds of gas and dust where stars are being born in this nebula.

sources.name: X-Ray
sources.context: The Chandra X-ray Observatory “sees through” the dust to reveal the location of hundreds of the very hottest stars being born in this nebula.

categories.title: Take Your Own Telescope Image
categories.subtitle: Request your own telescope observation and have the image emailed to you.

pages.title: Lagoon Nebula
pages.subtitle: Request your own observation and have the image emailed to you.
pages.description: Resembling a pool of light in the sky, the Lagoon Nebula is a giant cloud of hot hydrogen gas glowing from the intense light of newborn stars. The Lagoon Nebula, like other star-forming regions, can give us an insight into the environment that gave birth to our own Sun 5 billion years ago. What color does the Lagoon look in your OWN color image?

pages.title: Whirlpool Galaxy
pages.subtitle: Request your own observation and have the image emailed to you.
pages.description: The Whirlpool is a beautiful face-on spiral galaxy 23 million light years away that is interacting with a small companion galaxy. The MicroObservatory Telescope Network will observe this object for you tonight, and deliver your image to you tomorrow.
pages.oldDescription: A beautiful face-on spiral galaxy, the Whirlpool's spiral pattern was first seen and sketched in 1845. At first, it was unclear whether astronomers were looking at a whole city of stars a long way off, or simply one nearby star and its newly formed planetary system. The WhirlpooL has a small companion galaxy that is interacting with the larger spiral galaxy.

pages.title: Cigar Galaxy
pages.subtitle: Request your own observation and have the image emailed to you.
pages.description: The Cigar Galaxy, located in the sky near the Big Dipper, has a distorted shape and lots of starburst activity lighting up the center of the galaxy. The MicroObservatory Telescope Network will observe this object for you tonight, and deliver your image to you tomorrow.
pages.oldDescription: The Cigar Galaxy's (M82) distorted “starburst” shape is due to the gravity from its twin, M81. Inside dust clouds, thousands of new stars are being born. The winds generated by these white-hot new stars and old giant stars dying in supernova explosions are blowing fountains of gas out of the galaxy!

pages.title: Moon
pages.subtitle: Request your own observation and have the image emailed to you.
pages.description: What phase is the Moon in today? If it’s a new moon (near the Sun in the sky), your observation may be delayed a day or two. Otherwise, the MicroObservatory Telescope Network will observe this object for you later today or tonight, and deliver your image to you tomorrow.
pages.oldDescription: Your image of the Moon may be delayed a few days if the visual position of the Moon as seen from the Earth is located too close to the Sun

pages.title: Sun
pages.subtitle: Request your own observation and have the image emailed to you.
pages.description: Your image of the Sun will be sent as soon as the robotic telescopes are able to observe with clear skies!

pages.title: Hercules Star Cluster
pages.subtitle: Request your own observation and have the image emailed to you.
pages.description: This star cluster, located 22,000 light years away in the direction of the constellation Hercules, is a dense ball of hundreds of thousands of stars. The MicroObservatory Telescope Network will observe this object for you tonight, and deliver your image to you tomorrow.
pages.oldDescription: Hercules cluster, also called M13, is dense ball of hundreds of thousands of stars. M13 is one of over a hundred “globular clusters” that orbit the center of our Milky Way Galaxy. Globular clusters are ancient, and their 12 billion year-old stars are among the oldest in the Universe.

pages.title: Orion Nebula
pages.subtitle: Request your own observation and have the image emailed to you.
pages.description: The Orion Nebula is a huge colorful cloud of gas and dust where new stars are forming and is visible to the unaided human eye. The MicroObservatory Telescope Network will observe this object tonight through red, green, and blue filters, and deliver 3 raw images to you tomorrow with instructions for combining them into full color.
pages.oldDescription: The Orion nebula is an immense stellar nursery where clouds of dust and gas collapse under gravity to make the next generation of stars. It is also the closest star-forming region to us, and can be seen with the unaided eye in the constellation of Orion. Bright newborn stars at the center of the nebula make the nebula glow.
